choices.text: GnRH agonists
Laparoscopic hysterectomy
Laparoscopic myomectomy
Review ultrasound after 1 year

questions.text: A 45-year old presents for a routine gynecological checkup. She is having regular cycles with normal flow and mild dysmenorrhea on the 1st day. She is a non-smoker and has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her last pap smear was 2 years back which was reported to be normal. An ultrasound shows the presence of a 4 x 4 cm intramural fibroid with a sub-serosal component. She is very anxious and seeks your opinion on what should be done.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Review ultrasound after 1 year

Explanation:

  • This is an asymptomatic fibroid
  • Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.
  • Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid

Other Options

  • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid
  • Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism. 
  • Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. 

Educational Objective:

Management of symotomatic fibroids can be medical or surgical or newer non invasive techniques 

1. Medical Management

  • Non Hormonal:
    • NSAIDs for pain and heavy bleeding
    • Anti-fibrinolytics (Tranexamic acid): For heavy bleeding
  • Hormonal
    • Combined OCPS
    • SPRMs
      • Ulipristal acetate
      • Mifepristone
    • LNG-IUS: in small fibroids NOT distorting the uterine cavity
    • GnRH agonists
    • GnRH antagonists

2. Surgical Management

a. Myomectomy (Laparoscopic/ Laparotomy/ Hysteroscopic for submucous myomas)

b. Hysterectomy: Preferred in women who are not wanting future fertility with large/ multiple symptomatic fibroids
 

3. Non invasive

a. Magnetic Resonance Guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS)

b. Uterine artery embolization

 

*Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

choices.text: Advise MTP
Laparoscopic myomectomy
Analgesia and hydration
Hysterotomy and myomectomy

questions.text: A 23-year primi is presents at 16 weeks pregnancy with acute abdominal pain. On examination, the uterus is 20 weeks size and there is tenderness over the abdomen. An ultrasound reveals, a 6 cm fibroid in the anterior wall. What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Analgesia and hydration

Explanation

  • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy.
  • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • Pain is the predominant symptom.
  • Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs

Other Options

  • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve
  • Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy
  • Option C: Hysterotomy and myomectomy: Nor indicated in red degeneration of fibroid

Educational Objective: 

  • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • Pain is the predominant symptom.
  • Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs

Ref: Page no 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology

choices.text: Calcific degeneration
Fatty degeneration
Hyaline degeneration
Red degeneration

questions.text: The most common degeneration seen in uterine fibroids is
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyaline degeneration

Explanation

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Red degeneration, calcific degeneration and fatty degeneration are other kinds of degeneration in fibroids 

Educational Objective:

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Ref: Page no 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology

choices.text: Adenomyosis
Fibroid polyp
Leiomyoma
Ovarian mass

questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation

  • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.
  • On examination, this is  a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids)
    • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular
    • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)
    • The woman is nulliparous

Other Options:

  • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size)
  • In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding
  • In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

Educational Objective: 

C/f of fibroid uterus

Symptoms

  • Menorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Abdominal mass and pressure symptoms

Signs:

  • Uterus regularly enlarged (single fibroid) or irregularly enlarged (multiple fibroids)
  • Transmitted mobility is felt in a fibroid 

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic myomectomy
Hysteroscopic myomectomy
Reassurance
GnRH agonists

questions.text: A 27-year woman who is anxious to conceive visits the OPD with her husband. They have been trying to conceive for 2 years. She has regular periods with heavy flow. There is associated dysmenorrhea. A transvaginal scan shows a submucosal fibroid of about 2 cm in size. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Explanation:

This patient is infertile and has a submucosal fibroid. The fibroid has to be removed. Type 0 and 1 submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically

Other Options

  • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids
  • Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed.
  • Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility. 

Educational Objective:

  • Indications of myomectomy in infertility are:
    • Submucous fibroids
    • Large intramural fibroids distorting the cavity.
    • Intramural fibroids > 5cm
  • Submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically (Esp type 0 and type 1)

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: At the infundibulopelvic ligaments
At the level of round ligaments
At the level of the internal os
At the level of the fibroid

questions.text: You are assisting the surgeon in an abdominal myomectomy. The surgeon applies this instrument. Where would this be applied?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. At the level of the internal os

Explanation

  • This is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp
  • It is applied at the level of the uterine arteries  (level of internal os) during abdominal myomectomy to reduce the intra-operative blood loss by occluding the uterine arteries temporarily

Educational Objective:

  • This is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp
  • It is applied at the level of the uterine arteries  (level of internal os) during abdominal myomectomy to reduce the intra-operative blood loss by occluding the uterine arteries temporarily

Ref: Page no 527, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 7th edition

choices.text: Ovarian cystectomy
Myomectomy
Tubal recanalization
Vaginal hysterectomy

questions.text: The instrument shown below is useful in which surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myomectomy

Explanation:

  • The image is of a myoma screw. 
  • It is an instrument used in myomectomy. 
  • Myomectomy is a conservative surgery for fibroid uterus
    • It can be performed via laparotomy or laparoscopically
    • Risk of bleeding. This can be reduced
      • Preoperatively
      • GnRH agonists: They also reduce the size of the fibroid 
      • Correction of anemia/ blood transfusion
      • Uterine Artery Embolization
    • Intra-operatively
      • Use of Bonney’s uterine clamp/ uterine tourniquet (tied at the level of the uterine arteries)
      • Use of vasopressin: injected along the planned serosal incision

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The image is of a myoma screw. 
  • It is an instrument used in myomectomy. 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Bonnie’s clamp during surgery
Bilateral Uterine artery ligation
Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma
Use of vasopressin along the planned serosal incision

questions.text: A 36-year lady presents with menorrhagia. On evaluation she is found to have a large intramural fibroid. A myomectomy is planned. All are beneficial in reducing blood loss during surgery except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma

Explanation: 

Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma will not help reduce blood loss significantly during  a myomectomy

Educational Objective:

  • Myomectomy is a conservative surgery for fibroid uterus
    • It can be performed via laparotomy or laparoscopically
    • Risk of bleeding. This can be reduced
  • Preoperatively
    • GnRH agonists: They also reduce the size of the fibroid 
    • Correction of anemia/ blood transfusion
    • Uterine Artery Embolization
  • Intra-operatively
    • Use of Bonney’s uterine clamp/ uterine tourniquet (tied at the level of the uterine arteries)
    • Use of vasopressin: injected along the planned serosal incision

 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Cervical fibroid
Submucosal fibroid
Endometrial cancer
Subserous fibroid

questions.text: A 30-year woman underwent a diagnostic hysteroscopy for heavy menstrual bleeding. This image is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Submucosal fibroid

Explanation:

  • This is a hysteroscopic view of the uterine cavity showing a submucosal fibroid

Educational Objective:

  • A hysteroscope provides vision inside the uterine cavity
  • A submucosal fibroid on hysteroscope would appear as shown below

 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Endometrial Biopsy
LNG-IUD
Myomectomy
Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal  What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endometrial Biopsy

Explanation:

  • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.
  • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.
  • A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause. 
  • Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Educational Objective:

  • Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states
  • Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd  edition

choices.text: Type 0
Type 1
Type 2
Type 3

questions.text: A 34-year with menorrhagia is diagnosed to have a submucosal fibroid with < 50% protrusion in the endometrial cavity. She is FIGO type?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Type 2

 

<50% protrusion in the endometrial cavity means >50% is intramural. Hence the answer is type 2.

 

Explanation:

 

FIGO Classification of fibroids is as shown:

 

Ref: https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1016/j.ijgo.2010.11.011

choices.text: Endometrial ulceration
Dysfunctional uterine contractility
Increased endometrial surface area
Increased uterine vascularity

questions.text: A 23-year with heavy menstrual bleeding is diagnosed to have fibroids. She is curious to know why fibroids cause heavy bleeding. Which of the following is not a cause of heavy bleeding in fibroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endometrial ulceration

Explanation:

  • Fibroids cause heavy menstrual bleeding because of several reasons including
    • Increased endometrial surface area
    • Increased vascularity
    • Dysfunctional uterine contractility
    • Associated endometrial hyperplasia and PID

Educational Objective: 

  • Fibroids cause heavy menstrual bleeding because of several reasons including
    • Increased endometrial surface area
    • Increased vascularity
    • Dysfunctional uterine contractility
    • Associated endometrial hyperplasia and PID

 

 

Ref: Page no 527, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 7th edition

choices.text: Improve anemia, pre-operatively
Perimenopausal women
Shrink the size of the fibroid pre-operatively
Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

questions.text: Which is not an indication for medical management of fibroid uterus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

Explanation:

The indications of medical management in fibroid uterus is

  • Patients not desirous of fertility but wanting uterine preservation
  • Small symptomatic fibroids
  • Improving anemia
  • Peri-menopausal
  • Pre-op to shrink the size of the fibroid

In an infertile woman, any submucosal fibroid, even if small has to be removed

Educational Objective:

Remember if a woman is infertile; remove

  • Submucosal fibroids
  • Intramural fibroids
    • > 5 cm
    • Distorting the endometrial cavity

 

Ref: Page no 527, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 7th edition
